CLIMATOLOGY.

19



THE CLIMATE OF MARYLAND.

—_————

By LORIN BLODGET,
AUTHOR OF “AMERICAN CLIMATOLOGY,” ETC.

THE configuration of Maryland is very variable,
giving a wide tract nearly at sea-level in the
east and south, a moderately rolling district occupy-
ing the central part of the State, and a sharply cle-
vated mountainous belt crossing the summits of the
Alleghanies in the west. The climate has, therefore,
a wide range, from the soft maritime air of the At-
lantic coast, along the eastern shore, to the compara-
tively cold and severe atmosphere of the mountain
counties. The south-eastern extremity of the State
has the broad Chesapeake Bay to moderate its ex-
tremes,-as well as the Atlantic coast and the not
remote Gulf Stream. It is, therefore, much like
Norfolk and the Carolina coasts, and but little be-
yond the range of the live-oak and the cotton- and
rice-fields. Yet none of these are quite successful
within its limits. The summer heats of the interior
are greatly tempered here, and in many respects the
climate is delightful. Inland, and on leaving the
shores of the Chesapeake Bay, the extremes of heat
and cold alike are greater, and such as generally
belong to the latitude. Altogether, Maryland has a
climate sensibly warmer and softer than the average
of the States of the Atlantic coast.

In the central part of the State the range of single
extremes is great, and may be stated at 10° below
zero for the lowest, and 100° above for the greatest
heats of summer. In the country about Baltimore
and Washington such is the range : extremes ot 100°
in summer have been several times recorded, one
such instance occurring in June, 1853 ; while records
of 95° to 98° are quite frequent, and may be ex-
pected every summer. These extremes are not
greater, however, than is every year experienced as
far north as New England, though a greater number
of hot days will be observed in Maryland. During
these heats the atmosphere is usually more dry and
clastic than further north. As to cold extremes,
observations as low as 10° below zero have been re-
corded at Washington, and sometimes a period of
continuous cold occurs, covering the ground with
snow for two or three months. 1In 1856-7 such se-
verity prevailed from January to March, the use of
sleighs being constant at Washington and Baltimore.
Ice formed to the depth of twelve or fifteen inches
on the Potomac River, and on the shallow arms of
Chesapeake Bay. DBut such severity is rare, and

“may be expected only at intervals of about twenty-
five years. Generally, the winters are open and
mild, without much snow, and with very little ice.
A larger share of fair weather prevails at this season
than in any States northward.

The average temperature for the year at Balti-
more is 54°, being three degrees warmer than New
York city, and one and a half degrees warmer than
Philadelphia. The isothermal lines recede much on
the mountains, however, while they advance to but

little higher figures in the maritime districts. The
summer mean at Baltimore is 75°, being two and a
half degrees warmer than New York, and one degree
warmer than Philadelphia. The winter average is
34° at Baltimore, being two and a half degrees
warmer than New York, and nearly one and a half
degrees warmer than Philadelphia. In the extreme
southeast the winter average rises five degrees higher,
being nearly as warm as Norfolk, which is 40° for
the winter. At Crisfield, Snow Hill, and Salisbury,
this mild winter climate is conspicuous, as also in
St. Mary’s County, west of the Bay. At Frederick,
in the western central part of the State, the climate
is that of Philadelphia, very nearly. Further west,
and among the mountain valleys, the averages are
nearly those of Pittsburgh, though colder in the
higher districts. No records exist for these more

-



elevated localities : they are identical in -climate, as
in configuration, with the mountains of Pennsylvania
and Virginia.

The quantity of rain falling on the eastern shore,
within the cooling influence of the Atlantic, is only
about 42 inches; but inland, and along the borders
of Chesapeake Bay, the quantity rises to 46 inches
nearly. Rains are here conspicuous for the quantity
falling in single storms, though no greater number
of storms or proportion of cloudy weather exists,
than in other districts where a less aggregate depth
falls. In the range from Baltimore to Washington

the quantity falhng is about 44 inches. Then it falls

off to 42 inches, and again to 40 on the eastern slope
of the mountains, with but 38 in the higher localities.
Nearer the Ohio River the quantity increases again,
but this is beyond the boundary of Maryland.

Great as is the quantity of rain falling, the atmos-
phere is free from excessive humidity or great sen-
sible saturation. The proportion of fair and fine
weather is large at all seasons, probably one-third
to one-half greater than in the latitude of New York.
The increase in aggregate depth of rain is due to the
great quantities falling in single storms. These
heavy rains cause frequent floods in the streams and
rivers of the State, particularly in spring and early
summer. The range in the quantity of water falling
in a single month may be from a mere fraction of
an inch to sixteen inches; and in extreme years the
quantity for one year may amount to twice as much
as falls in a dry year.

As has been said, however, the atmosphere is not
saturated or unhealthy from this large rain-fall. The
general climate is bracing and healthy; the low and
marshy borders of the Bay and of the streams of
the east afford local malaria, but not of a severe or
dangerous character. Nor is the State liable to
dangerous fevers, or other diseases of tropical cli-
mates.

The following tabular statements illustrate the
averages of temperature and of the quantity of rain
falling in Maryland, within a reasonably near ap-
proximation, yet they are not as full as they should
be, and need to be supplemented by observations
taken within the limits of other States. The aver-
ages of temperature are relatively more full, and the
determinations more exact than those of the quantity
of rain. The range in extreme years is not so great
as to obscure the result, even if a very limited period
is embraced; while with observations of the quan-
tity of rain, the range in extreme years is such as to
render positive determinations difficult with less
than twenty years of continuous observation. There
is also frequent deficiency in the quantity recorded,
the excess in heavy rains not being all included, and
snow not being melted, or estimated for. The po-
sition of the instruments must also be carefully
adjusted, to make the record full. The records at
the military post at Baltimore, and all the stations
at Washington, are probably deficient in quantity.

The great range in temperature between extreme
months or seasons may be illustrated by citations
from the record at Fort McHenry, Baltimore, where
we have twenty-nine years of continuous observa-
tion, 1831 to 1859.

Maryland in winter were in 1831, 1856, and 1857;

The tables of quantity of rain cannot be so well
